title: ‘You need thick skin and wits about you to make it in this political environment’

title: ‘Very great and diverse company that I would love to join back and highly recommend for any friends that are planning to consider to join Telstra.’

title: ‘Worth everyday and helped me to grow as a person and have a better understanding of people.’
pros: Customer service, people, promotional nights, bonuses

title: ‘Better Together’

title: ‘Great place to learn a lot about big business and your own business acumen’

title: ‘I tried to do the best job I could in difficult circumstances, but was despised for it.’
pros: I enjoyed the physically demanding and intellectually stimulating nature of the job in my work as a Field Technician over 35 years in various customer-facing roles. I found that working in company with groups of individuals who had the commitment to provide the best that they could to a very high standard to be both educative and inspirational. The people I worked with were open and willing to giving advice and assistance without hesitation or prejudice. While it was impossible to avoid personality conflicts all of the time, mutual respect for the individual was evident due to the knowledge, skills, capabilities, and experience that each of my colleagues possessed. I enjoyed the challenges related to the problem-solving aspects of my day-to-day work as they continued to help me learn and develop my knowledge and skills. I gained satisfaction in the belief that I was trying to make a worthwhile contribution to the country and that I was involved in an industry that contributed to the nations' prosperity.
cons:
As a member of the field workforce in various roles over 35 years service, the greatest challenges revolved around giving service to the country in an industry that, by and large, was vital to the economic and social development of the community as a whole. As an individual working in a rapidly evolving technological field, the challenges related to maintaining currency with the latest technologies and systems were constant and unrelenting. These difficulties were met with resolve and persistence in order to gain the required mastery and proficiency necessary to continue working in the field. In addition to our daily activities, each of us in the field were obligated to maintain 24 hour availability when not on duty. The added stress of being required to respond to reports where there was a risk to public safety meant that we were never able to get sufficient rest in order to meet the next days challenges.
The greatest challenges originated from within those parts of the organisation not directly associated with the customer-facing sections of the organisation. In addition to the inertia and restrictions placed on the field workforce by the management and administrative parts of the organisation, vested, sectional, and political interests affected the overall perceptions of how each individual in the field was regarded and treated  by the community. These perceptions tended largely to be extremely negative, and coloured the opinions and reactions of the vast majority of the population. 
In that period between 1990 and 2007, I was working in a part of the organisation that was highly visible and therefore extremely vulnerable to the negative and anti-social attitudes and behaviours that were exhibited by a large proportion of the general populace throughout that period of time. Virtually all of the publicity generated from outside of the organisation was negative, derogatory and disparaging of the organisation, and each incident further inflamed the situations I found myself in each and every day.
The organisations' management were disinclined to offer any  explanation to counter any and all claims from any source against us , and this situation imbued most of us in the field with the belief that the work we were doing was not worthwhile or appreciated by any one person in the community.

pros: Good salary package, benefits, work/life balance. It's a comfortable place to work for with a large scope of benefits. It offers lots of opportunities like part-time work, annual / purchase leave etc.
cons: It's not a meritocracy, lots of politics and management it's more about who you get on well with and how you're perceived than about how good you are or perform in your job. Management tends to care more about politics than doing the right thing.

title: ‘A career defining span that polished existing skills and paved the way for my future accomplishments.’
pros: Career development opportunities, training (funded), management experience, free broadband, mobile staff rate, company car (private), and definitely the friends I made.
cons: Minimal contingency of fail-over staff in the event of UPA or rec. leave. Forced to take an involuntary redundancy package a result of the GFC

title: ‘As a long term employee, I've had some great experiences, but felt that my skills weren't always utilised to the maximum.’
pros:
In recent years the company has become much more conscious of work/life balance and working environment (esp. Future Ways of Working); while the effort put into the latter was admirable, there was an expectation that this would suit everyone, and it didn't.
Diversity is well integrated into the company culture, and on the whole management are both focused and caring.
cons:
I have personally felt that development opportunities could have been managed better - in some areas this probably works well, but for all the theory about job rotation etc, the practicalities didn't always add up.
Being caught up in numerous reorganisations can derail your career progresssion.

title: ‘Love the people, love my job, just wish was set hours.’
pros: Many development opportunities. Great people, supportive environment. Base wage is good, bonus incentives are great for those who work hard.
cons: Work life balance is hard. Rotating shifts make regular routines impossible.

title: ‘Telstra provides me a great work place where I can honestly say I'm happy to be.’
pros: Telstra is great at providing an engaging and diverse work environment. They honestly attempt to provide great flexible work arrangements.
cons: Unfortunately being a part of the biggest Telecommunications company in Australia means that many customers expect you to provide services where it is not always possible

title: ‘I loved working for Telstra but the environment has changed so much in the last few years, it has become a horrible company to work for.’
pros:
Some flexibility, including the ability to work from home with certain roles.
Some jobs (eg, technical call centre consultant and team leader roles) are extremely well paid - up to 6 figures).
cons:
Too much reliance on offshoring everything. 
Very little training provided, restructuring means that they move people around and give them new roles that they are not qualified for.
Too many inexperienced managers with no suitability to be people managers.
Performance appraisals are hopelessly subjective and \"peer reviews\" are just as bad.

title: ‘A whole continuum in one company excellent to terrible. Research the area well.’
pros: Flexible working, extra holiday, buy more leave, great career starter, innovation labs.
cons:
Centralised control so highly bureaucratic. I suspect many advertised roles on T's website are pre appointed and advertised for union compliance only.
Serious lack of management accountability widespread.

title: ‘Worst 2 years of my career , would not recommend it at all’
pros: The team I employed and worked with. Also my peers that were under the same environment but were great people !!
cons: Terrible culture , poor senior leadership, a disconnect from the Exec level to the front line. Dishonesty , moving the goal posts, inappropriate behaviour not managed and often encouraged

title: ‘Lots of flexibility to encourage good work-life balance’
pros:
Good reward and recognisation system.
Diversity in staff
Donations/sponsorship of communities and charities.
cons:
Old systems and processes which are clunky nad convoluted. Time consuming to learn and also to use.
Some bad management decisions.
Not good at managing poor performing staff.

title: ‘Telstra will grow you in all aspects of your career. It will also push you to the edge of your professionalism.’
pros: A focus of work life balance. Career development opportunities and great company culture
cons: Way too many levels of middle management and no departmental communication

title: ‘Very stressful with little to no support, best experience was leaving the company’
pros: Benefits and perks, company car, laptop, mobile phone, staff discount
cons: No career development for Field Technicians, no career progressment, overseas call centres are atrocious, no support for field technicians, upper management constantly restructure the company advising it will better serve the customer but in reality they are stripping skilled workers from the company to outsource jobs which impacts significantly on customer service and overall job satisfaction, all to put more money in their pockets. The company lacks direction and many employees are concerned for their future employment. I worked in Telstra for 12 years and did all training that was offered, not much opportunity in terms of climbing the ladder unless you were interested in Team Leading

title: ‘Get everything you need to succeed and grow.’
pros: Provides support within the team, management and head office. Feel like you are given the tools and support to reach and exceed your goal. Have a whole new world open up as you meet amazing customers, team members and other professionals every day.
cons: Daunting introduction to the industry. Customer interactions can turn with the snap of the finger. Remember to use your team.

title: ‘Overall just a great environment to work in whether it be in sales or a support role.’
pros: Variety. There's  a role to suit just about anyone. From face to face sales to behind the scenes support there's many opportunities to further develop your skill set.
cons: Because of the brand name you can never please 100% of your customers. But if you like what you do you can get pretty close.

title: ‘I recommend Telstra to anyone who wants to work as a team, to bring great products and great service to consumers.’
pros:
When working in a large store, weekly catch ups were organised for staff, by staff, at different venues to have a drink with each other and socialise.
The company was worth working for, and I advocate Telstra for their customer service, and fantastic network.
cons:
IPhone releases were the biggest challenge for me. I didn't like telling customers that they had to write their details on a waiting list that was 3-5 weeks behind in demand. The stores were crowded and I couldn't give the customers the service that they asked for, and deserved.
It didn't help when they were upset and threatened to purchase the phones from elsewhere, or to change their telco.

title: ‘Love working at Telstra Store’
pros: It's Fun at work. Everyday is different and exciting. People are friendly, management is great and supportive
cons:
Follow up with different departments takes lot of time which delays customer resolution. 
Not enough rights to do certain things, have to escalate certain things to different people/ department

title: ‘Telstra is Good Bad and Ugly all at the same time.’
pros: HR benefits, flexible working, fixed pay improvements annually can get salaries to a position significantly more than average over time, good severance pay (in the good section as Telstra rotate staff regularly). Great graduate programme, and young people career start opportunities. Good technology R&D and innovation exposure available.
cons:
A big company - setup like many smaller operations so the experience can be anywhere from absolutely brilliant to absolutely terrible.
Wastes so much money it is embarrassing. Many of the management lack leadership abilities. The atmosphere is often described as \"Toxic\". A lack of respect for people. Lots of customer complaints. Telstra bags its suppliers. Doesn't live the company values. You have to have thick skin to survive there.

title: ‘Initially I had a great time with Telstra, however they are constantly changing the expectations of consultants. Until it affected my bonuses and pay, I did not mind, but they have altered the job I /have/ to do, compared to the job I signed up for.’
pros: The salary is good for an entry-level position with no previous experience/qualification. Fantastic training upon starting the job.
cons: The job expectations are constantly changing, the KPIs are unrealistic based on expectations set by management and opportunities for development limited to \"favourites\" among management.

title: ‘An excellent addition to the CV and great potential in the right role with the right manager.’
pros: Good staff discounts and excellent flexible working conditions for corporate staff. Perfect for achieving work/life balance. A leader in flexible working.
cons: Management changes and leadership were hit and miss. The goal posts constantly change when it comes to hitting KPIs and achieving bonuses.

title: ‘The learning curve has been very steep for me and I have been able to deliver tangible results’
pros: You are empowered to deliver and make choices. Business supportive of new ideas and new ways of doing things more efficiently
cons:
So many broken process which consume colossal amount of time which leaves very little or no time to work on interesting stuff that deliver real value. 
Management only concerned about hitting the targets to collect their bonuses and case less about the business as a whole

title: ‘Great people poor management!’
pros: For a graduate who wants to gain a lot of experience and willing to put in long hours it is a good learning environment.
cons:
There are too many management layers and these managers have been there for 30+ years without experience in other markets. They are not open to new ideas or methods of delighting the customer. Telstra has the following layers:
Marketing, Sales, Products, Engineering, IT, and Operations with the only group with P&L being Marketing, so therefore every other group is treated as a cost centre. Senior managers get caught in the trap of meeting KPI's to get bonuses rather than thinking holistically about the good of the company. This results on downward pressure on good individuals who are cascaded KPI's that are basically unachievable.

title: ‘If you're going to work in ICT, it's the best game in town.’
pros: Fast paced, exciting environment.  Great office facilities, and very focussed on culture and employee engagement.
cons:
Micro management, poor leadership. Even at the highest levels. 
A culture of fear driving performance. 
Redundancies everywhere particularly for older folk, while recruiting much younger and cheaper capability. Not sure if this is by design.

title: ‘The best job i ever had.’
pros: Working for Telstra was great in all aspects you would want in a job. You were made to feel like you were part of the company, as a family unit and everyone from management to customer service consultants were very friendly, respectful and worked together as one. I have not experienced that anywhere else that I have worked.
cons: The most challenging thing I found was keeping up with the constant change with products and services. I didn't find anything difficult as the company provided exceptional training and constant assistance in order to help you with performing your job to the best of your ability.

title: ‘Probably what you would expect. A solid 3 stars.’
pros: Generally, Telstra runs a tight ship and has a lot in place to protect their employees. Flexible rostering is generally available and you get 25% off your Telstra bill by being a part of the team.
cons: They no longer throw around the word meritocricy, because it isnt. If you aren't in with the right crowd, your personal ability is almost meaningless. There is not as much support as is advertised which was one of my drivers for applying.

title: ‘I wouldn't work there because, my creative side was not being utilised enough. I do make some mistakes. However, through my learning come's a better me. Great place to work. I was motivated everyday. I always had something to look forward to...’
pros: Great work flow and team to play with. I can't forget my good friend Michael Minkarious and Wayne Stevens who has continued to support my music. He found me some opportunities that I later decided I didn't like because all I have ever wanted to work in is the media and entertainment business. I would have that team coupled with a great agent by the name of Artemis Navrozidis who was the first person that picked up my call and helped me find this job. I have always recommended her for great duties in her career path.
cons: There were never enough expertise to complete the incoming work capacity as would be required by a big corporation that states to the masses, \"It is the Number One Supplier Of a Product or Service.\" Telstra is a big name that requires a good team and creates jobs for many. That is the Telstra that I picture. By keeping It's employees, it will make itself the bigger company among many that have given up on human effort.

title: ‘The job taught me many skills in life, the most important one's being, people skills and respect’
pros: For me it was the ability to teach others how to do the work and bonding with other people. I didn't want to leave, would cherish a second opportunity
cons: Making sure clients demands were met. Having jobs completed in allotted time and safe manner.

title: ‘One year in Telstra is like 5 in another company. ’
pros: There used to be freedom to focus on building out leading customer solutions. The hierarchical nature on paper has gone but only time will tell if the ivory towers crumble.
cons: Inconsistent management, lack of clarity and poor strategy. There is little to know inclusion of teams. Enterprise wide agile will be rolling out but that doesn’t fix the focus on numbers and dropping the ball on enabling meaningful customer experiences. Still need to fix the basics. I wouldn’t expect the musical chairs at a senior level to minimise as the confussion and pour strategy continues. The con to this is there is now little to no career progression available. A lot of the strong leadership has jumped ship.

title: ‘Great company, always changing for the better’
pros: People you work with are great and always supportive, management  is always looking to improve and ensuring  all staff members are trained  on the latest and greatest. great insentives  for emplyees and always room to move in that career direction.
cons: Reaching  targets are always a challenge . Dividing your time for sales and client support. This work place is always changing, so adapting at times when you've just gotten  used to something is a challenge

title: ‘Good place to work with friendly staff.’
pros:
1) Hard work is recognized by the management. 
2) Excellent flexibility. E.g. Work from home.
3) Great Staff Benefits and Perks. 
4) Career growth options in Telstra are very good.
cons:
1) Teams spread out in Australia hence not all teams sit together. 
2) Some Managers can micro manage even if you are on a individual contributor role. 
3) Telstra has 2 contracts for old employees and newer employees with a huge pay gap. (higher pay for the older contract employees).

title: ‘Challenging but valuable’
pros: At Telstra you get to interact with all kinds of customers and it is a really valuable customer service experience and a good opportunity to build up your confidence. Team members are all friendly and supportive so there is a great of sense of community. The employee benefits are awesome, too.
cons: It is often hard dealing with some difficult customers. Sometimes there may be rude and un-understanding customers. This is where you need to learn to stay calm, don't take anything personally, be understanding and still try to offer a good solution for the customer. However if the customer continues to abuse you, you need to be firm and tell them that you won't be able to serve them because everyone deserves to be treated with respect. Also the store can get very busy sometimes so you will need to be able to work under pressure.

title: ‘Great people in a challenging situation.’
pros: The staff and the great attitude of upper management. The work life balance and the way they want Telstra to be for staff and customers alike. The really care for staff and want all to reach their full potential.
cons: Learning all the systems, the changes with NBN. The frustration with introducing new systems that have not had the bugs ironed out you. Having to deal with a third party that can't get the roll out of technology to run smoothly.

title: ‘A life changing opportunity with excellent challenges.’
pros: Telstra was an incredible environment to work in. The management staff were caring and friendly, team mates were always vibrant, would love to work there again one day.
cons: Difficult customers can always be daunting. But that isn't a problem with supportive staff and happy team mates by your side!

title: ‘Grateful to have worked in the team I was in’
pros:
I was lucky enough to be in a team with great managers and colleagues.
The managers I had were incredibly encouraging, supportive, understanding and went well beyond their roles as managers. They chose the team that I was apart of and the team members were all great to work with everyday. Honestly didn’t feel like I was working, just getting a job done with mates.
cons: The only challenge came at the end of the programme we were in when we were all let go.

title: ‘Working at Telstra is extremely challenging and rewarding, and an excellent goal for any technical engineer.’
pros: Working in a technical team at Telstra is beyond anything I have ever experienced before. Every member of the team was extremely skilled and dedicated, which fostered an incredible atmosphere of learning and collaboration. My line manager was easily the best direct manager I've ever had, and did everything in his power to make sure that his team had everything they needed to perform at their best, as well as shielding them from external concerns. While there was a good amount of after hours work, it was all paid in full as overtime, and stand-down periods the next day meant that you could recharge your batteries and not get worn down.
cons: While Telstra is slowly transforming into a modern, dynamic company, there are still a few echoes of government ownership which pop up now and then. Lots of meetings, at least in the area I was working, sometimes got in the way and felt like they could have been replaced with a quick huddle at someone's desk.

title: ‘I truly loved working for Telstra and if the right opportunity arose I would love to return’
pros:
25% staff discount on my monthly bill
The old commission structure- unfortunately corporate greed changed that so we had to work harder for less
Atmosphere
Excellent training program
Good opportunities for career development
CEO and other Honchos actually visited our centre a few times and met and mingled with staff.
cons:
Financial pressures caused management to have to push us harder and staff found it hard to see the point when our commission was taken away
IT issues- however we worked with it and around it but I guess with such a large network of systems you should expect issues

title: ‘I have worked across Telstra for many years and some areas are great, but a number are poorly run and managed.’
pros: Some parts of Telstra are great and they act in accordance with the values they promote. Telstra is a huge company that is quite diverse across telecommunications and IT. Some part of Telstra actually want to do the right thing by the customer but a number of the current systems and processes they have make it difficult in many situations of delivering the right outcome.
cons: Telstra Defence program is appalling. They have deliberately tried to maximise profit at the expense of the customer.

title: ‘Great flexible working tools’
pros: Great opportunities to work anywhere in Australia, good remote working tools, great people and lots of opportunities for diverse types of work
cons: Very hierarchal, too much red tape

title: ‘It is an ok place to work though batter jobs at like Western Power/Alinta Gas etc pay much better and set hours of work compared to Telstra varied/rotating shift work each week.’
pros: Good staff, variety of work,
cons: Systems crash, process obstacles, commission/benefits cut in half or do not exist for most people (too many KPIs preventing good pay), management strict, no freedom to be personal anymore (all scripted to a degree), rotating shift work each week, not paid enough for the stress.

title: ‘Couldn't think of a better place to work, how fortunate I was to work there. Wouldn't hesitate to go back!’
pros: My colleagues made it so easy for me to come to work. Digital is a great BU to work with - fun, upbeat, innovative, funky and oh so many talented people. I worked on a special project on a subject completely new to me and I built it from the ground up, solo. Not something you get to do everyday! Management are always encouraging of team building events and social activities.
cons: As with any company, it usually comes down to budget. Things like approvals can be pretty slow moving and with multiple levels, but when you're talking about the kind of money involved in my project and the impact it would have on the company, it was completely understandable and I had no issue with that. Every role has it's ups and downs, but for me this one had positives far outweighing the negatives.

title: ‘It is a big ship so it is slow to move but when it does it changes the whole landscape.’
pros: Amazing work/life balance with a massive push towards working from home for parents (I am not one but I do appreciate this benefit for parents as kids require them to be home)
cons: A lot of change in Media and it never felt there was continuity with management goals.

title: ‘Skilled retail like no other, help thousands of people, families, businesses. very low pay/appreciation.’
pros: Great company, easier to endorse the best. I know the numerous systems very well. I enjoy helping people and problen solving.
cons:
Hard to get noticed/move up. 
Constant shifting of targets to prevent commissions/bonuses. Frontline budget cuts

title: ‘Working  with the Telstra family’
pros: Working with a team you would call family with leaders who lead by example....Telstra would  create an awesome  environment  and support all the way
cons: Working in complaints  ...taught  you compassion. .dealing with all types of people and issues ...learning to turn unhappy people to great ones by getting the correct tools and getting the job done right first time

title: ‘20 years is a long time and it's been a great ride!’
pros: Excellent flexibility for work life balance.  There is variety in the work available and there are always new staff incentives and deals.  The company is focused on improving infrastructure and service.  It's nice to work for a place that is at the forefront of improving communication for the country.
cons: Some systems are outdated or tedious to use making it difficult to provide efficient customer service.  It can sometimes feel that the company is profit driven rather than customer orientated.

title: ‘I was happy to work with Telstra through all its name changes but it was a different time and company.’
pros: I worked for Telstra for over 40 years. I worked on many types of communication equipment and the diversity of technology and people was a very enrichening experience.
cons: The rapid change in technology and pressure to sell new products constantly makes Telstra a very stressful place to work and is most suitable to the young and dynamic. Like all businesses today the DOLLAR is paramount and upper management pushes that barrow in many different fashions.

title: ‘A dynamic busy environment that is always busy with a wide variety of challenges to work with on a daily basis.’
pros:
Great experience working in a very busy environment
Good support structure within store
cons:
Stress as a result of understaffing
Targets are high and a hugh tendency of changing targets so hard to embed good employee performance behaviours
Micro-managing with line managers

title: ‘Good for short time experience, bad for long term project’
pros:
Flexible and relaxed working environment
working with multiple technologies and vendors
cons:
Defence project is the worst. 
managers do not manage the team, just focused on their goals
no planning or schedule for the work, just push and push
too much politics and team are full of people who just can talk but no actions

title: ‘Worst workplace, unsupportive management, toxic and negative’
pros: The regular customers are nice and friendly and are the only good thing about working for Telstra Bathurst
cons: The workplace is very toxic and negative. There were many days it was difficult getting out of bed knowing you were working

title: ‘My years at Telstra has provided me with experience, knowledge and fond memories that has enriched my life.’
pros: The culture, the camaraderie between management and staff, striving to achieve a common goal, makes for a great working environment. Flexibility with work/life balance enable me to work part time after I had my 2 children.
cons: Telstra often goes through organisational restructures, which generally leads to management changes, department closures or reducing staff numbers. This causes undue unrest with staff.

title: ‘Challenging, interesting, frustrating and enjoyable all at the same time.’
pros: I had the opportunity to really step up, be challenged, and take action. I had loads of opporutnities to develop my skills, and to fill the gaps that came about in the project. Great team to work for, locatioin was awesome, as was the ability to be able to work from home when needed.
cons: Immediate project manager severely lacked management/leadership skills, and refused to have the difficult conversations. As a result, the team were placed in an undesireable predicament, and the editorial team placed under a massive amount of pressure that almost saw the project fail. :(

title: ‘Lots of great people that eventually lose their motivation due to the stretching of the rubber band till it breaks. Management put in place to achieve unrealistic targets & pressure filters all the way down. Work from home because it can be toxic in the o’
pros:
Work life balance
Opportunity to work at a higher level than your employment
cons:
Get ready to do the work of many.
Bureaucracy 101
Groundhog day

title: ‘Good and bad’
pros: The department I worked in always had different things that needed doing, kept things interesting instead of doing the same rote task. The team all worked well together and my immediate managers were great.
cons: The people above your immediate managers normally have absolutely no clue what you actually do day by day but they are the ones who make sweeping changes about how you do the work. Quite frequently you will have to find ways to tell customers it is Telstra at fault without being supposed to tell them it was Telstra fault.

title: ‘Great company to work for, really enjoying this opportunity’
pros: Very focused on employee welfare & wellbeing, lots of opportunities to grow & develop. Trust underpins so many things!
cons: Getting used to working with people based all over the country with video calling & associated technology.

title: ‘Would work with Telstra again in a heart beats’
pros: Fantastic Environment on the project I was working on, great team of incredibly talented people!
cons: Working under a new to Telstra people leader, very challenging!!!!

title: ‘Great for a short period of 1-3 years, don't stick to it as a career unless you're in management or higher’
pros:
- Great for a first job, you'll learn the concept of customer service and sales. 
- only benefit is staff mobile plans which are a lot cheaper than consumer plans
- you'll learn about the industry which will be valuable for the rest of your life, as when you're older and you start to sign up on your own plans, you'll know the hidden terms/conditions and loopholes of the telecommunications industry
cons:
- If you work in a franchised store then it'll be more sales driven, if you work in a store owned directly by Telstra, then you'll still have KPIs but you have a higher hourly rate but they're more focused on customer service
- It's a customer service role, you will have some difficult customers occasionally
- System that Telstra uses has its occasional issues, making it an awkward interaction with customers since you can't do much to help them
- You're the first point of contact for Telstra, people will lash out at you
- Not great as a career, only as a casual/part-time job like university students

title: ‘A great place to progress your career path and learn useful skills that are transferable into other companies and roles.’
pros: Plenty for opportunity for career development.  Walk the talk when it comes to diversity and equal opportunity.  Scope to move into a different role whilst remaining in the same company.
cons: Red tape that comes with working in a large organisation.  A single individual can hamper your career path or dictate your performance review, even though it is called a peer review.

title: ‘Would definitely recommend Telstra to a friend, loved my time there! ’
pros: Great career development. You get rewarded for the effort you put in. Supportive team and colleagues together with good management. The skills you can develop with Telstra can set you up for your career as the training offered is fantastic. The working agreements/entitlements are great such as sick leave, purchased leave and maternity leave etc.
cons: Highly regulated environment and working towards multiple (& often conflicting) targets.

title: ‘Exciting fast paced environment, with the opportunity to speak to a diverse group of people, and help them connect to other people around the world’
pros:
The in store teams are amazing to work with. 
The face to face experience is the most rewarding. 
You get to meet new people everyday and assist them to connect with their family and friends.
Being able to experience new technology first hand.
cons:
Complaint handling.
System based issues / billing issues.
Lack of training programmes.

title: ‘Was a good place to work and very professional’
pros: Learn a lot and have a good work life balance. Easy to get weekends and holidays when you want them. Very accommodating with maternity leave. Not a stressful job by any means.
cons: Pushed “team” environment but had to work individually and competitively if you wanted to make any commissions, which made work hostile at times.

title: ‘Worth considering as a career option.’
pros: Lots of opportunities to grow your knowledge base especially as they move more into Asia. While the salary is low compared to the rest of the industry, they do have a large number of benefits that are available to employees.
cons: Growing demands and reduced headcount often lead to you needing to work extended hours on a regular basis. Promotional opportunities for internal staff are low in a number of areas as the preference is to bring in externals.

title: ‘Would never again.’
pros:
The pay was good and the team that we often had was good.
(staff turnover was huge though because most people hate being literally screamed at by owners and management)
cons:
Managing so many complaints that have nothing to do with you.
Poor management and owners. (Most staff are screamed at daily)
Over-stress about hitting high daily targets.

title:
‘Started off well but breadth of changes made every day life difficult. Their mantra now is break everything and see what we can live without. 
People going left right and centre HR can't keep up. No role clarity and constant mantra of cost cutting regardl’
pros:
Flexibility of hours and ability to work from home.
So much change brings opportunity.
cons:
Constant restructuring and changes to the point management can't even tell whats going on or team structures and roles.
Worthwhile tasks are made redundant because they are always done re-actively and with no time.
Very much just feel like a small cog in the machine with so much secret squirrel stuff going on that management can't talk to you about.
Lot of central functions moved overseas which is cumbersome, slow and often providing incorrect information.

title: ‘Good company with some great benefits and they can be quite supportive.  Just Management need to get a firmer grasp on the reality of thier customers concerns.’
pros: The people you work with.
cons: Upper management being out of touch with reality.  The KPI's can be hard to manage due to the diverse nature of Telstra's customers.  Too strong a push towards Sales when they should be looking at Customer Service, Satisfaction and advocacy first and foremost.

title: ‘Loads of people are made redundant.  But CEO gets a 30% pay rise.’
pros: Good resources, but that is declining due to redundancies.
cons: Outsource is breaking things, then you are under pressure and cop the blame.  Place is a mess.

title: ‘Demoralizing and money grubbing. ’
pros: The days off are great.
cons:
Meeting targets to be able to make commission can be extremely hard and when you do the reward of commission is unsatisfying. 
Work life balance does not exist because the company only prioritises itself and making money. Doesn't care for their employees or their needs. Scrutinise you if you don't meet their unrealistic expectations .

title: ‘Avoid at all costs’
pros: The pay is decent, the career development opportunities are what you make of it. There are good benefits and perks
cons: Terrible management, no leadership or vision, broken systems and non-existent processes.

title: ‘Avoid it as the politics are ridiculous’
pros: The perk are the bonuses (when you do get them) are great and have a relationship with alot of big corporations so there are corporate discounts.
cons: Continually micromanaged and the targets are sometimes unrealistic. because there is soo many management in the food chain its hard to get a straight answer. forget about worklife balance. management expects your whole life to revolve around work and be a robot as such. over the years discounts for telstra services went down as did bonuses yet the kpis went up

title: ‘I made a rewarding career from the bottom up and was offered development opportunities that allowed me to move through various roles in various states.’
pros: Great support for all employees in relation to diversity and opportunity. Employee benefits and award conditions are excellent
cons: Rapid leadership changes can lead to stalling in personnel development plans

title: ‘Too much politics.’
pros: Flexible work arrangements and a \"as long as you get your work done I don't care what you do\" attitude is the best part about Telstra. Generally a fairly good working atmosphere also.
cons: Constantly restructuring. Multiple levels of management and company policy can make things like getting a pay rise very difficult (max raise is generally 10% without director approval, independent of role changes).The flexible working arrangements can become a hassle when relying on key resources to complete work in time.

title: ‘An open door to opportunity and success’
pros: Definitely the pay, the salary is as average as any retail full time position. The commission structure is what's most impressive.
